text.p: These are the leading stories in the Sarajevo press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The Moslem-Croat federation parliament is obstructing attempts by the government to resolve a number of social and economic problems, daily says in a comentary after the parliament failed to pass several laws.

- International donors conference for Bosnia's reconstruction will not be held until the entities make concensus on certain economic issues, says Colum Murphy, spokesman to the international High Representative to Bosnia Carl Bildt.

- Ruling Moslem Party of Democratic Action (SDA) will not meet Bosnian Serb Democratic Party (SDS) until indicted war criminals are sent to the International Criminal Tribunal for former Yugoslavia in the Hague, SDA spokesman Ismet Grbo says.

- Mayor of disputed Bosnian town of Brcko in exile, Munib Jusufovic, resigns after the town's international supervisor Robert Farrand decides that all expelled citizens who want to return to Brcko must accept identification documents from Bosnian Serb republic.
- There is still no final decision on whether returnees to the Serb republic will have to take Bosnian Serb identification documents, officials from Carl Bildt's office say.
- Bosnian Serb citizens of Brcko stone two buses carrying Bosnian Moslem refugees during their visit to town for the International Labor Day.

- Moslem-Croat federation prime minister, Edhem Bicakcic, meets chief of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) mission in Bosnia, Scott Brown to discuss the central bank and new Bosnian currency due to be issued in September. -- Sarajevo newsroom, +387-71-663-864
